p: The function of these mutations is unknown, but in other systems adaptations after host shifts have been found to enhance the ability of the virus to bind to host receptors [ 11], increase replication rates [ 16] or avoid the host immune response [ 8, 10, 47]. Of the high frequency significant SNPs (shown in Fig 1 with red asterisk) nine occur in the non-structural proteins (ORF1: RNA dependant RNA polymerase, the putative protease and helicase proteins), and eleven occur in the capsid proteins (ORF2). Interestingly, none were in DCV-1A, which suppresses the host antiviral RNAi defences [ 48]. It will be of interest to examine the functions of the parallel mutations we detected, and characterise phenotypically how they affect viral infectivity and replication.
